There's so much more we can say about this issue, but the bottom line is this: we can and should be producing our energy right here at home, using a sustainable, all-of-the-above energy approach.

Simply trying to halt leasing and production does nothing to accomplish that goal.

MYTH: we don't need to be developing federal land.

FACT: not all federal land is a national park or monument. In fact, most of it isn't. With 640 million acres - almost 30% - of U.S. land under federal control, we should be sustainably using it.

MYTH: there's no environmental harm in importing our oil from overseas.

FACT: when we produce energy domestically, we control the environmental regulations, pollution standards, methods of transportation, etc. When we outsource production, we lose control of these safeguards.

MYTH: banning energy production on federal land will kickstart renewable energy.

FACT: energy bans only affect the supply, not the demand. Our entire infrastructure simply cannot switch to being exclusively renewables-based overnight. Anyone who believes otherwise is wrong.

MYTH: domestic energy production is bad for the environment.

FACT: not only is energy production cleaner and safer than ever, but these royalties also support a variety of environmental programs. For example, offshore oil and gas funds LWCF, which supports outdoor recreation.

MYTH: conservatives don't care about the environment, they just want to use and abuse the land.

FACT: conservatives have initiated some of our most effective environmental policy. We just don't believe conservation has to come at the cost of American jobs and energy dominance.
Let's get into some myths vs. facts when it comes to energy production on federal lands and waters. There's a lot of misinformation out there, so it's important to set the record straight. üëá

Presiding over the U.S. Senate with one message in mind: Do good. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EssO7fEW8AAMVTG.jpg

MCCONNELL: If the Democratic majority were to attack the filibuster, they would guarantee themselves immediate chaos. If they went scorched-earth, this body would grind to a halt... Taking that plunge would not be some progressive dream. It would be a nightmare. I guarantee it.

RT @LeaderMcConnell Today, I made clear that if Democrats ever attack the key Senate rules, it would drain the consent and comity out of the institution. A scorched-earth Senate would hardly be able to function. It wouldn‚Äôt be a progressive‚Äôs dream. It would be a nightmare.

I guarantee it.

MCCONNELL: When factional fever runs hot and slender majorities are most tempted to ram through radicalism -- these are the times for which the guardrails exist. The nation needs us to respect the framers‚Äô design and the Senate‚Äôs structure.

RT @LeaderMcConnell The Senate requires collaboration and deliberation. It‚Äôs a feature, not a bug, that slim majorities can't ram through half-baked ideas.

My remarks on the legislative filibuster and why I stuck up for the minority‚Äôs rights even when Republicans had power: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X_TVxGfIOAI&feature=youtu.be

MCCONNELL: The Senate‚Äôs 60-vote threshold ensures narrow interests cannot ignore the rest of the country. It embodies Jefferson‚Äôs maxim that ‚Äúgreat innovations should not be forced on slender majorities.‚Äù

MCCONNELL: The bar for lawmaking is high. It should be high, even if both parties take turns being slightly frustrated by it. If your legislation can‚Äôt pass the Senate, you don‚Äôt scrap the rules or lower the standards. You improve your idea, take your case to the people, or both.

MCCONNELL: Eliminating the legislative filibuster would not speed the Democrats‚Äô ambitions. It would delay them terribly. And it would hamstring the Biden presidency over a power grab which the President has spent decades warning against and still opposes.

MCCONNELL: Republicans understand you don‚Äôt destroy the Senate for a fleeting advantage. We resisted pressure to destroy the legislative filibuster ourselves. Our friends across the aisle must see the same.

MCCONNELL: James Madison said the Senate‚Äôs job was to provide a ‚Äúcomplicated check‚Äù against ‚Äúimproper acts of legislation.‚Äù The Senate exists to make sure laws have broad buy-in. To stop bad ideas, improve good ideas, and keep laws from swinging every election.
